description: From Middle English bollard, probably from Middle English bole (“tree trunk”), equivalent to bole +‎ -ard (pejorative or diminutive suffix).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A strong vertical post of timber or iron, fixed to the ground and/or on the deck of a ship, to which the ship's mooring lines etc are secured.
A similar post preventing vehicle access to a pedestrian area, to delineate traffic lanes, or used for security purposes.
